Comments_List: general guide to data science. very applicable in helping me get a job.
learned how to use many machine learning models
Various tools for data science analysis. Improved R skills as well
Machine learning methods

How to use R to implement machine learning algorithms for parsing data (regression and classification). A moderate amount of necessary theory, and how to work with the relevant equations to prove results.
Statistical analysis all the way to modern machine learning techniques like deep convo. neural nets
Almost everything in ML is an extension of linear regression or k-nearest neighbors, and almost every parameter gets chosen using cross-validation. Except with random forests.
We learned about 30 different machine learning techniques. Really interesting class if you want a high level understanding of ML.
Machine Learning techniques, increased proficiency with working in R, applications of my statistical knowledge
Data analysis skills in ML

Basic understanding of many classification techniques in machine learning. Examples include K nearest neighbors, linear discriminant analysis, trees (lots of stuff with trees), and principal component analysis.
programming skills
I learned a variety of machine learning algorithms.
R coding, problem solving, and knowledge of contemporary machine learning methods.
random forest etc

Extensive machine learning knowledge
Problem solving

R programming skill
basic machine learning knowledge
practice a lot in R
R coding, non-parametric, non-linear models, tree-based models, neural networks, linear algebra, and MATH
Various basic knowledge and techniques of data mining skills.  The course was easy to understand and helpful for non-stats background people.
Data mining and machine learning
Developed familiarity and some facility with a number of data mining & machine learning techniques using R.
More statistics packages and algorithms in R
regularization, svm, bagging, boosting, lda, neural network
lectures are dry, not sure how to make them more interactive though... great homeworks.

cover lots of machine learning methods, very useful

currently all in R. would be better if can incorporate Python.
Very good selection of topics. But spent too much time with math maybe, and we can't understand those parts without outside materials.

Strengths: sample code, lots of relevant material, appropriate assignments. Piazza was very useful.

Improvements: please put one slide on the PDF for each slide, in contrast to one slide for each PowerPoint event (like a single line of text appearing). This improvement would make it much easier to study the course content, and digest the more difficult material. (I spent much of my time just scrolling through the slides to find the appropriate section).

Strengths: Great problem sets that forced us to understand what the algorithms would do and how to use them

Weaknesses: lectures got a bit boring
Too much time should be spent on six homework but HW only covers 40% of our grade.
The lectures and psets are well desgined and organized.

This course was a robust overview of standard machine learning techniques, introducing new methods through lecture and offering opportunities to apply the skills we learned on real, if already thoroughly explored, data sets, through homework assignments. I think many of the students would have preferred it if we had used, for example, Python as our base language instead of R. I would also have liked practice with a language like Python that's more widely used in industry. But overall, the course was a good one, a first taste of the power of ML.
The powerpoints were very boring and no one really paid close attention. It was nice that she integrated the applied parts to it.

Strengths: Good time spent between lecture notes and coding in class

Improvements: The level of engagement of the class could be increased, maybe with the aid of clickers. I know it's hard to have class engagement with such a large class size and there is a lot of material to go through, but sometimes pauses for questions or asking a question for the class to answer with long enough pauses for thought could help.
Too much assignment

Strengths: Good introduction to many popular and effective methods of machine learning. Certainly inspires me to take future courses in machine learning.

Weaknesses: both too much depth at times and not enough depth in others. For example,  often we would see some of the math behind the algorithms we worked with, but typically blitzed through such information, giving me very little to remember now. Similarly, we spent only a class or two on any given algorithm, giving us a basic understanding of each, but lacking some true conceptual understanding.

We did not cover many machine learning algorithms that most basic machine learning courses cover. I think the course should start from first principles and cover a wider breadth of material. The level of statistics background required for different topics was very highly variable.
the homework is a little bit over loaded
This course covers most of the core machine learning algorithms and it is not easy to do this within one semester.
Strengths: Excellent instruction; well designed assignments.

strengths: can learn a lot 
weaknesses: a bit fast and the lecture notes are not self explanatory enough

strengths: 
1. the lecture slides are clear
2. the homework helps me to get a deeper understanding of the course material
3. piazza is very helpful. I learned a lot from reading other student's post. And my question can get very quick feedback from piazza. It is a great way to learn
weakness:
1. It would be great if there is a project. I found that I always learn a lot from doing a project. 
2. Sometimes the homework can take a very long time to run. 
3. It would be great if the homework solutions can be posted online

Good programming practice course.
spend too much time on homework.

Strength: Up-to-date knowledge, practical skills
Weakness: overwhelming math problems, too much dedication to homework and still we have two exams to survive

Strengths: suitable for any levels of background if people are familiar with linear algebra. The class goes through R code in the class as well, so it helps people who haven't used R in the past as well.

Weakness: although it may be unpopular among students, additional 1-2 homeworks may have been helpful.

Strength: great intro to this field

Could be improved: might reduce the portion of the more simple topics or the overlapping ones with other courses, and gear towards more advanced topics

The techniques covered in this class were useful in my work, and I have already found ways to apply LASSO and kernel smoothing in other projects/applications. This class is billed as an "applied" class. However, the first questions on the homework were infallibly not "applied" questions. These questions were very theory-based in a way that was difficult but did not help me understand the techniques they applied to. In this regard, I found them to be largely a waste of time in that they cut into the time I could devote to the rest of the homework that tended to be more applied. I understand that given the size of class, it may not be feasible to have more in-depth student-driven projects, but this would have been most helpful to me. To illustrate, the applied homework problems tended to include instructions to clean and manipulate the data, with little instruction on how one would actually grapple with this for the given data mining/machine learning technique. Overall, given that this is an applied survey course, I would de-emphasize the under-the-hood mathematics (as important as they are) in both the lectures and the homework and use that time to focus on intuition and applications of these techniques.

covered all the essential topics
can dig a little deeper into the application of those methods
Ask open questions to let us explore the most suitable methods instead of step up step instructions
absolutely... if you have the prerequisites
Yes. very useful
Yes
Yes

Great course, definitely recommended. The material was directly applicable to my own datasets (and thus, other students' data). All I have to do is format my data in an appropriate .csv format, and I could run the algorithms to produce useful results. THANK YOU for that!

I started with 0 stat/machine learning knowledge and am now quite confident applying these techniques on my own. It was a lot of work --I had to put in extra study to understand concepts other students had already seen -- but I think it vastly improved my toolset as an engineer.

Yes, I would recommend this course. Its not proofs-based, and its hands-on, but a conceptual understanding is still emphasized and treated as a necessary foundation. So its a well-rounded first pass at ML techniques, and I found it valuable.
Yes. Great class for high level understanding.

I would recommend this class to students who have backgrounds in probability and statistics beyond an introductory level course. I think this could improve the amount of theoretical concepts learned in class (i.e. more time could be spent on the theoretical aspects if the professor can assume a certain level of prior knowledge)
Not because the workload is high
Definitely. I really enjoyed the introduction to machine learning, and think that this is a fascinating topic for almost any student.
Yes
I highly recommend students who are interested in machine learning to choose this course.
Yes.
Yes.

Yes. Machine learning is very useful in data related field. And this course is a introductory course with good organization. It covers lots of topic, but it is not hard to learn.  This course doesn't go very deep with the theoretical part. So it is a good choice for people who don't have much programming background but wants to know some basic concepts of machine learning. And I think taking this course can be a great preparation for other more theoretical machine learning courses.
Yes.  It is a good intro level course for student to learn machine learning and data mining
I'd really recommend it ONLY IF you have enough time for this class. This class demands HUGE amount of dedication. And you have to be familiar with lots of math knowledge to keep up with the class
Yes, totally for the reasons I wrote in 3.
A great introduction to this fancy world with acceptable level of workload.

I have recommended this course to other students with explicit and serious reservations and caveats. If the students' goal is really just to survey data mining & machine learning, this course may be appropriate. If you truly want to efficiently practice using and applying these techniques without spending a lot of time on work that does not help your understanding of the material, I would avoid the class.
Yes! This is a good statistic algorithm course

yes 
It is a good introduction to machine learning, deepened my understanding about data science
and it's the only machine learning course offered at Yale...
